an7.52:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā campāyaṃ viharati gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre.
an7.52:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Campā on the banks of the Gaggarā Lotus Pond.

an7.52:1.2.pli: Atha kho sambahulā campeyyakā upāsakā yena āyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho campeyyakā upāsakā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavocuṃ:
an7.52:1.2.eng: Then several lay followers of Campā went to Venerable Sāriputta, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

an7.52:1.3.eng: “Sir, it’s been a long time since we’ve heard a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.

an7.52:1.4.pli: Sādhu mayaṃ, bhante, labheyyāma bhagavato sammukhā dhammiṃ kathaṃ savanāyā”ti.
an7.52:1.4.eng: It would be good if we got to hear a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.”

an7.52:1.5.eng: “Well then, reverends, come on the next sabbath day.

an7.52:1.6.pli: appeva nāma labheyyātha bhagavato sammukhā dhammiṃ kathaṃ savanāyā”ti.
an7.52:1.6.eng: Hopefully you’ll get to hear a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.”

an7.52:1.7.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho campeyyakā upāsakā āyasmato sāriputtassa paṭissutvā uṭṭhāyāsanā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkamiṃsu.
an7.52:1.7.eng: “Yes, sir” they replied. Then they rose from their seats, bowed to Sāriputta, and respectfully circled him before leaving.

an7.52:2.1.pli: Atha kho campeyyakā upāsakā tadahuposathe yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu.
an7.52:2.1.eng: Then on the next sabbath the lay followers of Campā went to Venerable Sāriputta, bowed, and stood to one side.

an7.52:2.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto tehi campeyyakehi upāsakehi saddhiṃ yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an7.52:2.2.eng: Then they went together with Sāriputta to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. Sāriputta said to the Buddha:

an7.52:3.1.pli: “Siyā nu kho, bhante, idhekaccassa tādisaṃyeva dānaṃ dinnaṃ na mahapphalaṃ hoti na mahānisaṃsaṃ;
an7.52:3.1.eng: “Sir, could it be that someone gives a gift and it is not very fruitful or beneficial,

an7.52:3.2.pli: siyā pana, bhante, idhekaccassa tādisaṃyeva dānaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahānisaṃsan”ti?
an7.52:3.2.eng: while someone else gives exactly the same gift and it is very fruitful and beneficial?”

an7.52:3.3.pli: “Siyā, sāriputta, idhekaccassa tādisaṃyeva dānaṃ dinnaṃ na mahapphalaṃ hoti na mahānisaṃsaṃ;

an7.52:3.4.pli: siyā pana, sāriputta, idhekaccassa tādisaṃyeva dānaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahānisaṃsan”ti.

an7.52:3.5.pli: “Ko nu kho, bhante, hetu ko paccayo yena midhekaccassa tādisaṃyeva dānaṃ dinnaṃ na mahapphalaṃ hoti na mahānisaṃsaṃ;
an7.52:3.5.eng: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason for this?”

an7.52:3.6.pli: ko nu kho, bhante, hetu ko paccayo yena midhekaccassa tādisaṃyeva dānaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahānisaṃsan”ti?

an7.52:4.1.pli: “Idha, sāriputta, ekacco sāpekho dānaṃ deti, patibaddhacitto dānaṃ deti, sannidhipekho dānaṃ deti, ‘imaṃ pecca paribhuñjissāmī’ti dānaṃ deti.
an7.52:4.1.eng: “Sāriputta, take the case of a someone who gives a gift as an investment, their mind tied to it, expecting to keep it, thinking ‘I’ll enjoy this in my next life’.

an7.52:4.2.pli: So taṃ dānaṃ deti samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ yānaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ seyyāvasathapadīpeyyaṃ.
an7.52:4.2.eng: They give to ascetics or brahmins such things as food, drink, clothing, vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; and bed, house, and lighting.

an7.52:4.3.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, sāriputta, dadeyya idhekacco evarūpaṃ dānan”ti?
an7.52:4.3.eng: What do you think, Sāriputta, don’t some people give gifts in this way?”

an7.52:5.1.pli: “Tatra, sāriputta, yvāyaṃ sāpekho dānaṃ deti, patibaddhacitto dānaṃ deti, sannidhipekho dānaṃ deti, ‘imaṃ pecca paribhuñjissāmī’ti dānaṃ deti.
an7.52:5.1.eng: “Sāriputta, someone who gives a gift as an investment,

an7.52:5.2.pli: So taṃ dānaṃ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an7.52:5.2.eng: when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the gods of the four great kings.

an7.52:5.3.pli: So taṃ kammaṃ khepetvā taṃ iddhiṃ taṃ yasaṃ taṃ ādhipaccaṃ āgāmī hoti āgantā itthattaṃ.
an7.52:5.3.eng: When that deed, success, glory, and sovereignty is spent they return to this place.

an7.52:6.1.pli: Idha pana, sāriputta, ekacco na heva kho sāpekho dānaṃ deti, na patibaddhacitto dānaṃ deti, na sannidhipekho dānaṃ deti, na ‘imaṃ pecca paribhuñjissāmī’ti dānaṃ deti;
an7.52:6.1.eng: Next, take the case of a someone who gives a gift not as an investment, their mind not tied to it, not expecting to keep it, and not thinking, ‘I’ll enjoy this in my next life’.

an7.52:6.2.pli: api ca kho ‘sāhu dānan’ti dānaṃ deti …pe….
an7.52:6.2.eng: But they give a gift thinking, ‘It’s good to give’ …

an7.52:7.2.pli: api ca kho ‘dinnapubbaṃ katapubbaṃ pitupitāmahehi na arahāmi porāṇaṃ kulavaṃsaṃ hāpetun’ti dānaṃ deti …pe….
an7.52:7.2.eng: They give a gift thinking, ‘Giving was practiced by my father and my father’s father. It would not be right for me to abandon this family tradition.’ …

an7.52:8.1.pli: Napi ‘dinnapubbaṃ katapubbaṃ pitupitāmahehi na arahāmi porāṇaṃ kulavaṃsaṃ hāpetun’ti dānaṃ deti;

an7.52:8.2.pli: api ca kho ‘ahaṃ pacāmi, ime na pacanti, nārahāmi pacanto apacantānaṃ dānaṃ adātun’ti dānaṃ deti …pe….
an7.52:8.2.eng: They give a gift thinking, ‘I cook, they don’t. It wouldn’t be right for me to not give to them.’ …

an7.52:9.1.pli: Napi ‘ahaṃ pacāmi, ime na pacanti, nārahāmi pacanto apacantānaṃ dānaṃ adātun’ti dānaṃ deti;

an7.52:9.2.pli: api ca kho ‘yathā tesaṃ pubbakānaṃ isīnaṃ tāni mahāyaññāni ahesuṃ, seyyathidaṃ—
an7.52:9.2.eng: They give a gift thinking, ‘The ancient brahmin seers were Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamadaggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, and Bhagu.

an7.52:9.3.pli: aṭṭhakassa vāmakassa vāmadevassa vessāmittassa yamadaggino aṅgīrasassa bhāradvājassa vāseṭṭhassa kassapassa bhaguno, evaṃ me ayaṃ dānasaṃvibhāgo bhavissatī’ti dānaṃ deti …pe….
an7.52:9.3.eng: Just as they performed great sacrifices, I will share a gift.’ …

an7.52:10.1.pli: Napi ‘yathā tesaṃ pubbakānaṃ isīnaṃ tāni mahāyaññāni ahesuṃ, seyyathidaṃ—

an7.52:10.2.pli: aṭṭhakassa vāmakassa vāmadevassa vessāmittassa yamadaggino aṅgīrasassa bhāradvājassa vāseṭṭhassa kassapassa bhaguno, evaṃ me ayaṃ dānasaṃvibhāgo bhavissatī’ti dānaṃ deti;

an7.52:10.3.pli: api ca kho ‘imaṃ me dānaṃ dadato cittaṃ pasīdati, attamanatā somanassaṃ upajāyatī’ti dānaṃ deti …pe….
an7.52:10.3.eng: They give a gift thinking, ‘When giving this gift my mind becomes clear, and I become happy and joyful.’ …

an7.52:11.1.pli: Napi ‘imaṃ me dānaṃ dadato cittaṃ pasīdati, attamanatā somanassaṃ upajāyatī’ti dānaṃ deti;
an7.52:11.1.eng: They don’t give a gift thinking, ‘When giving this gift my mind becomes clear, and I become happy and joyful.’

an7.52:11.2.pli: api ca kho cittālaṅkāracittaparikkhāraṃ dānaṃ deti.
an7.52:11.2.eng: But they give a gift thinking, ‘This is an adornment and requisite for the mind.’

an7.52:11.3.pli: So taṃ dānaṃ deti samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ yānaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ seyyāvasathapadīpeyyaṃ.
an7.52:11.3.eng: They give to ascetics or brahmins such things as food, drink, clothing, vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; and bed, house, and lighting.

an7.52:11.4.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, sāriputta, dadeyya idhekacco evarūpaṃ dānan”ti?
an7.52:11.4.eng: What do you think, Sāriputta, don’t some people give gifts in this way?”

an7.52:12.1.pli: “Tatra, sāriputta, yvāyaṃ na heva sāpekho dānaṃ deti;
an7.52:12.1.eng: “Sāriputta, someone who gives gifts, not for any other reason,

an7.52:12.6.pli: napi ‘dinnapubbaṃ katapubbaṃ pitupitāmahehi na arahāmi porāṇaṃ kulavaṃsaṃ hāpetun’ti dānaṃ deti;

an7.52:12.7.pli: napi ‘ahaṃ pacāmi, ime na pacanti, nārahāmi pacanto apacantānaṃ dānaṃ adātun’ti dānaṃ deti;

an7.52:12.8.pli: napi ‘yathā tesaṃ pubbakānaṃ isīnaṃ tāni mahāyaññāni ahesuṃ, seyyathidaṃ—

an7.52:12.9.pli: aṭṭhakassa vāmakassa vāmadevassa vessāmittassa yamadaggino aṅgīrasassa bhāradvājassa vāseṭṭhassa kassapassa bhaguno, evaṃ me ayaṃ dānasaṃvibhāgo bhavissatī’ti dānaṃ deti;

an7.52:12.10.pli: napi ‘imaṃ me dānaṃ dadato cittaṃ pasīdati, attamanatā somanassaṃ upajāyatī’ti dānaṃ deti;

an7.52:12.11.pli: api ca kho cittālaṅkāracittaparikkhāraṃ dānaṃ deti.
an7.52:12.11.eng: but thinking, ‘This is an adornment and requisite for the mind’,

an7.52:12.12.pli: So taṃ dānaṃ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā brahmakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an7.52:12.12.eng: when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn among the gods of the Divinity’s host.

an7.52:12.13.pli: So taṃ kammaṃ khepetvā taṃ iddhiṃ taṃ yasaṃ taṃ ādhipaccaṃ anāgāmī hoti anāgantā itthattaṃ.
an7.52:12.13.eng: When that deed, success, glory, and sovereignty is spent they are a non-returner; they do not return to this place.

an7.52:13.1.pli: Ayaṃ kho, sāriputta, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yena midhekaccassa tādisaṃyeva dānaṃ dinnaṃ na mahapphalaṃ hoti na mahānisaṃsaṃ.
an7.52:13.1.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why someone gives a gift and it is not very fruitful or beneficial,

an7.52:13.2.pli: Ayaṃ pana, sāriputta, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yena midhekaccassa tādisaṃyeva dānaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahānisaṃsan”ti.
an7.52:13.2.eng: while someone else gives exactly the same gift and it is very fruitful and beneficial.”

an7.53:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca sāriputto āyasmā ca mahāmoggallāno dakkhiṇāgirismiṃ cārikaṃ caranti mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ.
an7.53:1.2.eng: At one time the venerables Sāriputta and Mahāmoggallāna were wandering in the Southern Hills together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.

an7.53:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena veḷukaṇḍakī nandamātā upāsikā rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ paccuṭṭhāya pārāyanaṃ sarena bhāsati.
an7.53:1.3.eng: Now at that time the laywoman Veḷukaṇṭakī, Nanda’s mother, rose at the crack of dawn and recited the verses of “The Way to the Far Shore”.

an7.53:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena vessavaṇo mahārājā uttarāya disāya dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ gacchati kenacideva karaṇīyena.
an7.53:2.1.eng: And at that time the great king Vessavaṇa was on his way from the north to the south on some business.

an7.53:2.2.pli: Assosi kho vessavaṇo mahārājā nandamātāya upāsikāya pārāyanaṃ sarena bhāsantiyā, sutvā kathāpariyosānaṃ āgamayamāno aṭṭhāsi.
an7.53:2.2.eng: He heard Nanda’s Mother reciting, and stood waiting for her to finish.

an7.53:3.1.pli: Atha kho nandamātā upāsikā pārāyanaṃ sarena bhāsitvā tuṇhī ahosi.
an7.53:3.1.eng: Then when her recital was over she fell silent.

an7.53:3.2.pli: Atha kho vessavaṇo mahārājā nandamātāya upāsikāya kathāpariyosānaṃ viditvā abbhānumodi:
an7.53:3.2.eng: Then, knowing she had finished, Vessavaṇa applauded, saying,

an7.53:3.5.eng: “Sister, I am your brother Vessavaṇa, the great king.”

an7.53:3.6.pli: “Sādhu, bhadramukha, tena hi yo me ayaṃ dhammapariyāyo bhaṇito idaṃ te hotu ātitheyyan”ti.
an7.53:3.6.eng: “Good, dearest! Then may my recital of the teaching be my offering to you as my guest.”

an7.53:3.7.eng: ‘Good, sister! And let this also be your offering to me as your guest.

an7.53:3.8.pli: Sveva sāriputtamoggallānappamukho bhikkhusaṅgho akatapātarāso veḷukaṇḍakaṃ āgamissati, tañca bhikkhusaṅghaṃ parivisitvā mama dakkhiṇaṃ ādiseyyāsi.
an7.53:3.8.eng: Tomorrow, the mendicant Saṅgha headed by Sāriputta and Moggallāna will arrive at Veḷukaṇṭa before breakfast. When you’ve served the Saṅgha, please dedicate the religious donation to me.

an7.53:3.9.eng: Then that will also be your offering to me as your guest.”

an7.53:4.1.pli: Atha kho nandamātā upāsikā tassā rattiyā accayena sake nivesane paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādāpesi.
an7.53:4.1.eng: And when the night had passed the lay woman Nanda’s Mother had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in her own home.

an7.53:4.2.pli: Atha kho sāriputtamoggallānappamukho bhikkhusaṅgho akatapātarāso yena veḷukaṇḍako tadavasari.
an7.53:4.2.eng: Then the Saṅgha of mendicants headed by Sāriputta and Moggallāna arrived at Veḷukaṇṭa.

an7.53:4.3.pli: Atha kho nandamātā upāsikā aññataraṃ purisaṃ āmantesi:
an7.53:4.3.eng: Then Nanda’s Mother addressed a man,

an7.53:4.4.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, ambho purisa, ārāmaṃ gantvā bhikkhusaṅghassa kālaṃ ārocehi:
an7.53:4.4.eng: “Please, worthy man, go to the monastery and announce the time to the Saṅgha, saying:

an7.53:4.5.pli: ‘kālo, bhante, ayyāya nandamātuyā nivesane niṭṭhitaṃ bhattan’”ti.
an7.53:4.5.eng: ‘Sirs, it’s time. The meal is ready in the home of the lady Nanda’s Mother.’”

an7.53:4.6.pli: “Evaṃ, ayye”ti kho so puriso nandamātāya upāsikāya paṭissutvā ārāmaṃ gantvā bhikkhusaṅghassa kālaṃ ārocesi:
an7.53:4.6.eng: “Yes, Ma’am,” that man replied, and he did as she said.

an7.53:4.7.pli: “kālo, bhante, ayyāya nandamātuyā nivesane niṭṭhitaṃ bhattan”ti.

an7.53:4.8.pli: Atha kho sāriputtamoggallānappamukho bhikkhusaṅgho pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena nandamātāya upāsikāya nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
an7.53:4.8.eng: And then the Saṅgha of mendicants headed by Sāriputta and Moggallāna robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, went to the home of Nanda’s Mother, where they sat on the seats spread out.

an7.53:4.9.pli: Atha kho nandamātā upāsikā sāriputtamoggallānappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
an7.53:4.9.eng: Then Nanda’s Mother served and satisfied them with her own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.

an7.53:5.1.pli: Atha kho nandamātā upāsikā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
an7.53:5.1.eng: When Sāriputta had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Nanda’s Mother sat down to one side.

an7.53:5.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho nandamātaraṃ upāsikaṃ āyasmā sāriputto etadavoca:

an7.53:5.3.pli: “ko pana te, nandamāte, bhikkhusaṅghassa abbhāgamanaṃ ārocesī”ti?
an7.53:5.3.eng: “Nanda’s Mother, who told you that the Saṅgha of mendicants was about to arrive?”

an7.53:6.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, bhante, rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ paccuṭṭhāya pārāyanaṃ sarena bhāsitvā tuṇhī ahosiṃ.
an7.53:6.1.eng: “Sir, last night I rose at the crack of dawn and recited the verses of ‘The Way to the Far Shore’, and then I fell silent.

an7.53:6.2.pli: Atha kho, bhante, vessavaṇo mahārājā mama kathāpariyosānaṃ viditvā abbhānumodi:
an7.53:6.2.eng: Then the great king Vessavaṇa, knowing I had finished, applauded me,

an7.53:6.4.eng: I asked: ‘But who might you be, dearest?’

an7.53:6.5.eng: ‘Sister, I am your brother Vessavaṇa, the great king.’

an7.53:6.6.pli: ‘Sādhu, bhadramukha, tena hi yo me ayaṃ dhammapariyāyo bhaṇito idaṃ te hotu ātitheyyan’ti.
an7.53:6.6.eng: ‘Good, dearest! Then may my recital of the teaching be my offering to you as my guest.’

an7.53:6.7.eng: ‘Good, sister! And let this also be your offering to me as your guest.

an7.53:6.8.pli: Sveva sāriputtamoggallānappamukho bhikkhusaṅgho akatapātarāso veḷukaṇḍakaṃ āgamissati, tañca bhikkhusaṅghaṃ parivisitvā mama dakkhiṇaṃ ādiseyyāsi.
an7.53:6.8.eng: Tomorrow, the mendicant Saṅgha headed by Sāriputta and Moggallāna will arrive at Veḷukaṇṭa before breakfast. When you’ve served the Saṅgha, please dedicate the religious donation to me.

an7.53:6.9.eng: Then that will also be your offering to me as your guest.’

an7.53:6.10.pli: Yadidaṃ, bhante, dāne puññañca puññamahī ca taṃ vessavaṇassa mahārājassa sukhāya hotū”ti.
an7.53:6.10.eng: And so, sir, may the merit and the flourishing of merit of this gift be for the happiness of the great king Vessavaṇa.”

an7.53:7.2.pli: Yatra hi nāma vessavaṇena mahārājena evaṃmahiddhikena evaṃmahesakkhena devaputtena sammukhā sallapissasī”ti.
an7.53:7.2.eng: that you converse face to face with a mighty and illustrious godling like the great king Vessavaṇa.”

an7.53:8.1.pli: “Na kho me, bhante, eseva acchariyo abbhuto dhammo.
an7.53:8.1.eng: “Sir, this is not my only incredible and amazing quality;

an7.53:8.2.pli: Atthi me aññopi acchariyo abbhuto dhammo.

an7.53:8.3.pli: Idha me, bhante, nando nāma ekaputtako piyo manāpo.
an7.53:8.3.eng: I had an only son named Nanda who I loved dearly.

an7.53:8.4.pli: Taṃ rājāno kismiñcideva pakaraṇe okassa pasayha jīvitā voropesuṃ.
an7.53:8.4.eng: The rulers forcibly abducted him on some pretext and had him executed.

an7.53:8.5.pli: Tasmiṃ kho panāhaṃ, bhante, dārake gahite vā gayhamāne vā vadhe vā vajjhamāne vā hate vā haññamāne vā nābhijānāmi cittassa aññathattan”ti.
an7.53:8.5.eng: But I can’t recall getting upset when my boy was under arrest or being arrested, imprisoned or being put in prison, killed or being killed.”

an7.53:8.7.eng: that you purify even the arising of a thought.”

an7.53:9.1.pli: “Na kho me, bhante, eseva acchariyo abbhuto dhammo.
an7.53:9.1.eng: “Sir, this is not my only incredible and amazing quality;

an7.53:9.2.pli: Atthi me aññopi acchariyo abbhuto dhammo.

an7.53:9.3.pli: Idha me, bhante, sāmiko kālaṅkato aññataraṃ yakkhayoniṃ upapanno.
an7.53:9.3.eng: When my husband passed away he was reborn in one of the realms of spirits.

an7.53:9.4.pli: So me teneva purimena attabhāvena uddassesi.
an7.53:9.4.eng: He revealed to me his previous incarnation.

an7.53:9.5.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ, bhante, abhijānāmi tatonidānaṃ cittassa aññathattan”ti.
an7.53:9.5.eng: But I can’t recall getting upset on that account.”

an7.53:9.7.eng: that you purify even the arising of a thought.”

an7.53:10.1.pli: “Na kho me, bhante, eseva acchariyo abbhuto dhammo.
an7.53:10.1.eng: “Sir, this is not my only incredible and amazing quality;

an7.53:10.2.pli: Atthi me aññopi acchariyo abbhuto dhammo.

an7.53:10.3.pli: Yatohaṃ, bhante, sāmikassa daharasseva daharā ānītā nābhijānāmi sāmikaṃ manasāpi aticaritā, kuto pana kāyenā”ti.
an7.53:10.3.eng: Ever since we were both young, and I was given in marriage to my husband, I can’t recall betraying him even in thought, still less in deed.”

an7.53:10.5.eng: that you purify even the arising of a thought.”

an7.53:11.1.pli: “Na kho me, bhante, eseva acchariyo abbhuto dhammo.
an7.53:11.1.eng: “Sir, this is not my only incredible and amazing quality;

an7.53:11.2.pli: Atthi me aññopi acchariyo abbhuto dhammo.

an7.53:11.3.pli: Yadāhaṃ, bhante, upāsikā paṭidesitā nābhijānāmi kiñci sikkhāpadaṃ sañcicca vītikkamitā”ti.
an7.53:11.3.eng: Ever since I declared myself a lay follower, I can’t recall deliberately breaking any precept.”

an7.53:12.1.pli: “Na kho me, bhante, eseva acchariyo abbhuto dhammo.
an7.53:12.1.eng: “Sir, this is not my only incredible and amazing quality;

an7.53:12.2.pli: Atthi me aññopi acchariyo abbhuto dhammo.

an7.53:12.3.pli: Idhāhaṃ, bhante, yāvade ākaṅkhāmi vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
an7.53:12.3.eng: Whenever I want, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

an7.53:12.4.pli: Vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
an7.53:12.4.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, I enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

an7.53:12.5.pli: Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhikā ca viharāmi satā ca sampajānā sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedemi, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
an7.53:12.5.eng: And with the fading away of rapture, I enter and remain in the third absorption, where I meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

an7.53:12.6.pli: Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmī”ti.
an7.53:12.6.eng: With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.”

an7.53:13.1.pli: “Na kho me, bhante, eseva acchariyo abbhuto dhammo.
an7.53:13.1.eng: “Sir, this is not my only incredible and amazing quality;

an7.53:13.2.pli: Atthi me aññopi acchariyo abbhuto dhammo.

an7.53:13.3.pli: Yānimāni, bhante, bhagavatā desitāni pañcorambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni nāhaṃ tesaṃ kiñci attani appahīnaṃ samanupassāmī”ti.
an7.53:13.3.eng: Of the five lower fetters taught by the Buddha, I don’t see any that I haven’t given up.”

an7.53:14.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto nandamātaraṃ upāsikaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmīti.
an7.53:14.1.eng: Then Venerable Sāriputta educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired Nanda’s Mother with a Dhamma talk, after which he got up from his seat and left.

an7.54:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an7.54:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an7.54:1.2.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu ko paccayo yena sutavato ariyasāvakassa vicikicchā nuppajjati abyākatavatthūsū”ti?
an7.54:1.2.eng: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason why a learned noble disciple has no doubts regarding the undeclared points?”

an7.54:2.1.pli: “Diṭṭhinirodhā kho, bhikkhu, sutavato ariyasāvakassa vicikicchā nuppajjati abyākatavatthūsu.
an7.54:2.1.eng: “Mendicant, it’s due to the cessation of views that a learned noble disciple has no doubts regarding the undeclared points.

an7.54:2.2.pli: ‘Hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti kho, bhikkhu, diṭṭhigatametaṃ;
an7.54:2.2.eng: ‘A realized one still exists after death’: this is a misconception.

an7.54:2.3.pli: ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti kho, bhikkhu, diṭṭhigatametaṃ;
an7.54:2.3.eng: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death’: this is a misconception.

an7.54:2.4.pli: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti kho, bhikkhu, diṭṭhigatametaṃ;
an7.54:2.4.eng: ‘A realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death’: this is a misconception.

an7.54:2.5.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti kho, bhikkhu, diṭṭhigatametaṃ.
an7.54:2.5.eng: ‘A realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death’: this is a misconception.

an7.54:2.6.pli: Assutavā, bhikkhu, puthujjano diṭṭhiṃ nappajānāti, diṭṭhisamudayaṃ nappajānāti, diṭṭhinirodhaṃ nappajānāti, diṭṭhinirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ nappajānāti.
an7.54:2.6.eng: An unlearned ordinary person doesn’t understand views, their origin, their cessation, or the practice that leads to their cessation.

an7.54:2.7.pli: Tassa sā diṭṭhi pavaḍḍhati, so na parimuccati jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi. ‘Na parimuccati dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
an7.54:2.7.eng: And so their views grow. They’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They’re not freed from suffering, I say.

an7.54:3.1.pli: Sutavā ca kho, bhikkhu, ariyasāvako diṭṭhiṃ pajānāti, diṭṭhisamudayaṃ pajānāti, diṭṭhinirodhaṃ pajānāti, diṭṭhinirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti.
an7.54:3.1.eng: A learned noble disciple does understand views, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation.

an7.54:3.2.pli: Tassa sā diṭṭhi nirujjhati, so parimuccati jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi. ‘Parimuccati dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
an7.54:3.2.eng: And so their views cease. They’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They’re freed from suffering, I say.

an7.54:3.3.pli: Evaṃ jānaṃ kho, bhikkhu, sutavā ariyasāvako evaṃ passaṃ ‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na byākaroti;
an7.54:3.3.eng: Knowing and seeing this, a learned noble disciple does not answer: ‘A realized one still exists after death’,

an7.54:3.4.pli: ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na byākaroti;
an7.54:3.4.eng: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death’,

an7.54:3.5.pli: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na byākaroti;
an7.54:3.5.eng: ‘a realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death’,

an7.54:3.6.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na byākaroti.
an7.54:3.6.eng: ‘a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death.’

an7.54:3.7.pli: Evaṃ jānaṃ kho, bhikkhu, sutavā ariyasāvako evaṃ passaṃ evaṃ abyākaraṇadhammo hoti abyākatavatthūsu.
an7.54:3.7.eng: Knowing and seeing this, a learned noble disciple does not declare the undeclared points.

an7.54:3.8.pli: Evaṃ jānaṃ kho, bhikkhu, sutavā ariyasāvako evaṃ passaṃ na chambhati, na kampati, na vedhati, na santāsaṃ āpajjati abyākatavatthūsu.
an7.54:3.8.eng: Knowing and seeing this, a learned noble disciple doesn’t shake, tremble, quake, or get nervous regarding the undeclared points.

an7.54:4.1.pli: ‘Hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti kho, bhikkhu, taṇhāgatametaṃ …pe…
an7.54:4.1.eng: ‘A realized one still exists after death’: this is just about craving. …

an7.54:4.6.pli: ‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti kho, bhikkhu, vippaṭisāro eso;
an7.54:4.6.eng: ‘A realized one still exists after death’: this is a regret.

an7.54:4.7.pli: ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti kho, bhikkhu, vippaṭisāro eso;
an7.54:4.7.eng: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death’: this is a regret.

an7.54:4.8.pli: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti kho, bhikkhu, vippaṭisāro eso;
an7.54:4.8.eng: ‘A realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death’: this is a regret.

an7.54:4.9.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti kho, bhikkhu, vippaṭisāro eso.
an7.54:4.9.eng: ‘A realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death’: this is a regret.

an7.54:4.10.pli: Assutavā, bhikkhu, puthujjano vippaṭisāraṃ nappajānāti, vippaṭisārasamudayaṃ nappajānāti, vippaṭisāranirodhaṃ nappajānāti, vippaṭisāranirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ nappajānāti.
an7.54:4.10.eng: An unlearned ordinary person doesn’t understand regrets, their origin, their cessation, or the practice that leads to their cessation.

an7.54:4.11.pli: Tassa so vippaṭisāro pavaḍḍhati, so na parimuccati jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi. ‘Na parimuccati dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
an7.54:4.11.eng: And so their regrets grow. They’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They’re not freed from suffering, I say.

an7.54:5.1.pli: Sutavā ca kho, bhikkhu, ariyasāvako vippaṭisāraṃ pajānāti, vippaṭisārasamudayaṃ pajānāti, vippaṭisāranirodhaṃ pajānāti, vippaṭisāranirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti.
an7.54:5.1.eng: A learned noble disciple does understand regrets, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation.

an7.54:5.2.pli: Tassa so vippaṭisāro nirujjhati, so parimuccati jātiyā …pe… ‘… dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
an7.54:5.2.eng: And so their regrets cease. They’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They’re freed from suffering, I say.

an7.54:5.3.pli: Evaṃ jānaṃ kho, bhikkhu, sutavā ariyasāvako evaṃ passaṃ ‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na byākaroti …pe…
an7.54:5.3.eng: Knowing and seeing this, a learned noble disciple does not answer: ‘A realized one still exists after death’ …

an7.54:5.4.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na byākaroti.
an7.54:5.4.eng: ‘a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death.’

an7.54:5.5.pli: Evaṃ jānaṃ kho, bhikkhu, sutavā ariyasāvako evaṃ passaṃ evaṃ abyākaraṇadhammo hoti abyākatavatthūsu.
an7.54:5.5.eng: Knowing and seeing this, a learned noble disciple does not declare the undeclared points.

an7.54:5.6.pli: Evaṃ jānaṃ kho, bhikkhu, sutavā ariyasāvako evaṃ passaṃ na chambhati, na kampati, na vedhati, na santāsaṃ āpajjati abyākatavatthūsu.
an7.54:5.6.eng: Knowing and seeing this, a learned noble disciple doesn’t shake, tremble, quake, or get nervous regarding the undeclared points.

an7.54:5.7.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhu, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yena sutavato ariyasāvakassa vicikicchā nuppajjati abyākatavatthūsū”ti.
an7.54:5.7.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why a learned noble disciple has no doubts regarding the undeclared points.”
